Award.AwardTitle: Building a Big Data Analytics Workforce in iSchools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The significance and importance of this project resides in the introduction of big data analytics into the education landscape. There is increasing demand for skilled personnel in big data industries, but existing big data curricula at the university level focus primarily on students with a strong computational background, ignoring a large segment of students who might otherwise pursue education and training in this vital area, but who will be faced with big data issues in the workplace. This project aims at addressing the national demand for professionals with knowledge in big data and broadening the pool for a big data analytics workforce. Part of this effort will involve research as to whether the newly developed learning modules are more effective at increasing students' big data competencies, e.g., knowledge, skills, and analysis.

The goal of this project is to develop three innovative learning modules. These modules will be designed to: (i) utilize both group-based and contextualized learning methods and (ii) be applicable and accessible to students majoring in disciplines outside, but related to main-stream computer science (e.g., iSchools). The first module will involve digital exercises where students will be asked to develop their own narratives about the relevance and significance of big data in solving real-life problems and will be expected to become knowledgeable of, and proficient with, big data concepts and applications. The second module will be more technical in nature and will allow students to discover the efficacy of big data concepts in solving practical problems in information security. Finally, the third module will introduce more advanced topics in big data mining, such as examining a large amount of complex data to unearth important patterns and knowledge, and introducing how to interpret the results to arrive at appropriate decisions in a specific context. Analysis of the research question surrounding the learning effectiveness will employ quasi-experimental designs that use pretests and posttests with control groups. Students will choose a course section without knowledge of which section will include the new learning modules. In analyzing the data, a hierarchical linear modeling approach will be used to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed innovative learning modules based on both group-based and contextualized learning methods to build a big data analytics workforce in iSchools.

Big data refers to data growing exponentially in both volume and variety and defying conventional modeling, storage, search, analysis, or visualization approaches. As big data becomes more prevalent, big data analytics skills to analyze a massive and complex data set, and to eventually extract useful knowledge are also becoming increasingly important as well. Recognizing this need, the U.S. government announced a big data research and development initiative in 2012. The iSchools, as a new breed of interdisciplinary institutions that share a fundamental interest in the relationships among information, people, and technology, in general have curricula quite different from traditional computer science programs. As such, teaching big data analytics to iSchool students requires well-designed yet innovatively different approaches from those used in traditional computer science programs. Toward this challenge, we developed three different types of learning modules (digital storytelling about big data, security analysis in the cloud, and big data mining) and evaluated students’ learning once they are implemented in classrooms.

In this project, we strived to answer the following research question: How to develop innovative teaching materials under the big data analytics context to train undergraduate students with limited computing competencies effectively? To respond to this challenge, this project developed innovative big data analytics learning modules specifically designed for iSchool students with diverse academic backgrounds, who were taught in interdisciplinary curricula and therefore often lack the foundational knowledge necessary to learn core big data analytics concepts unlike traditional computer science students. The modular construction of the learning materials facilitates incremental learning for students. The learning modules are innovative due to the use of pedagogical approaches such as group-based learning and contextualized learning.

Our project has a direct impact on increasing the number and diversity of undergraduate students with computational competencies and big data skills.  After the initial trials at the University Park and Altoona campuses of Penn State, the proposed course modules were adopted by other campuses and institutions. Although the primary target audience for this project is the iSchool undergraduate student body, some of the developed learning materials can also be used for students with majors such as Library Information Systems (LIS) or Management Information Systems (MIS), who may require even more preparatory and background materials before being exposed to the big data analytics concepts. In addition, the beginner’s module (i.e., digital storytelling) contains information designed to raise awareness on the significance of and potential career opportunities in big data analytics field. For this reason, the beginner’s module can be used to recruit students into four year majors that can lead to jobs specializing in big data analytics.
